subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Okay, this sound very helpful at this stage, though others may point out problems. I will look at the link  you provide below for other such sets. Note how
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
> > > But we don't have to put up with "iksent" or "ayksunt" for "accent"
> > > (instead of "aksent"), if we accept the principle that Et is used for
> > > whatever sound functions in the writer's dialect the way short-e
> > > functions in "mainstream" dialects.
> >
> > Sounds like a nice idea. How would you write the definition of Et such
> > that beginners in all accents understand it?
>
> Nothing could be simpler! We say:
>
> Write the letter #28 Et for the vowel you use in words like
> "dress", "step", "ebb", "hem", "pet", "leg", "shelf", "effort",
> "threat", "bread", "ready", "any", and "friend". Note: if you
> pronounce the words "pin" and "pen", and "Jim" and "gem", the
> same, you will have to remember to use #28 Et in the words that
> Orthodox writes with "e".

Okay, this sound very helpful at this stage, though others may point out
problems. I will look at the link you provide below for other such
sets. Note how this is different from the QS manual, which gives just
one word as if that word were a perfect example, and more importantly,
does *not* deal with problems such as those speakers who pronounce "pen"
and "pin" differently. (When I moved to the Midwest from Boston, people
started talking about ink pens, rather than just pens. It took me a
while to figure out why.)

Let me raise one very, very hypothetical example. Let us say that in two
generations QS becomes the standard alphabet and TO no longer exists.
(This is *not* going to happen, mind you.) You are training a children
to write. If that child pronounces "pen" like "pin" what do you say? I
suppose you would simply have to point out that other speak differently
than that child, and he needs to use Ed for "pen."

Paul
